title: The worst thing you can do to a champ is to break them on account of pro play
body: Pro play is meant to service the playerbase of league of legends, not serve as a basis to invalidate champs for 99 percent of players.

replies.body:
> [{quoted}](name=Hexs Fortune,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=YcAEWK3I,comment-id=,timestamp=2019-03-23T21:36:16.071+0000)
>
> Pro play is meant to service the playerbase of league of legends, not serve as a basis to invalidate champs for 99 percent of players.

THANK YOU!

Pro play is completely irrelevant to most of the playerbase, balancing around it is ridiculous. Riot should balance around high elo, NOT pro play.

There's nothing that justifies ruining a champion for the average playerbase that uses said champion every day because of pro players who will stop using the champion as soon as they find something better to abuse.
It should be balanced around the average player.... let the small pro base go nuts with broken builds and champions. 90% of the player base won't care
The boards would have an aneurysm if Riot balanced around the average player, since then they'd balance the entire game around Bronze/Silver.
until those builds make it into high elo and trickle down into silver/gold/plat

Pro play has a major influence on player behavior, builds, etc. When a champ dominates the arena of pro play, I understand the reasoning to adjusting the champ. Pro play by nature influences our decision making and thus it too must be kept in check to keep the whole community balanced. Pro players are selecting champs based on statistics and what is dominant. Pro Play selections therefore are indications of champs that may be overly powerful.

I'm not saying that I like it, but it is necessary fact of math.

Do you have an idea on how to counter act the influence of Pro players?

If a champion is really that insane in pro play to the point where they are worthless for 99% of the playerbase, they should just be turned off in pro. I'm serious. Riot banned funnel strategy and a couple other degenerate strategies from pro play over the years even before the strategy had in-game nerfs.

Back in the day it was just Azir and Ryze. Now it seems like every month a champion is getting shit on because of pro play and it honestly makes the game feel shallow.

Well that's not a good idea. "Turn off a champion in pro play" also already happens with lower-skill champions who don't bring enough to pro play to warrant being picked.

While a controversial opinion, I think having certain characters busted in pro play but shit in pug play is good. Players who want to use these champions should aspire to them, practice hard and really have to knuckle down. Having everyone be pickable for even the most average player feels rather bad. Riot's super guilty of this as well with things such as the Alistar pulverize change or taking cool mechanics like the Ryze zhonya's warp and removing them "so it's easier for everyone".

I'm also fine with them being busted as shit in pro play and not being nerfed down because of it. Pro play champions are usually high skill cap so hard to use in lower ranks as is, but when they are "balanced" around pro play they are basically unusable for everyone.

Either they should do my first suggestion and just turn the worst offenders off in pro matches, or they should allow the Shurima shufflers, Q>E>W>Q>E>Q>E>Q>E>Q spammers, teammate eaters, girlfriend shielders, and other characters to break pro play and let regular people also have the chance to learn them. Right now we have the worst system, where champions who aren't even that good but have an interesting mechanic pro play likes on a team comp get absolutely dumpstered to the point where only the most hardcore mains will keep playing them. Any solution which returns pro play nerfed champions to regular people gets a thumbs up from me.

There's no such thing as "learning for average player" when pro players expose a dominant champion with a dominant strategy, with a dominant build. Players simply adopt the exact same play style as seen pro players and they're no longer niche or a sleeper pick because it's out in public for hundreds of thousands of players. Even if only a small portion of these viewers replicate the same results with the same champ, they don't even nearly have to be as skilled as pros to be able to reap the higher win rate rewards.

LCS is what sets the trend because the best of the best pit against each other in teams.
It doesn't matter if you in particular don't give a shit about LCS and don't watch it, you don't even have to watch it to come across a strategy that was directly taken pro play because you've likely seen it from a player that cloned it, which has seen it from someone else who cloned it, etc.

People like to ignore the fact that LCS dictates trends.
Big LoL streamers dictate trends. If League didn't have this online coverage, we'd have to find our own ways by scraping YT videos, stat sites and finding our own way and adopting widely accepted and seen strategies, or by the word of mouth.

Also, it isn't like any of the pro play changes make the game worse. If anything, changes directed at keeping solo queue such as keeping riven and zed overpowered because they are popular hurts the game far more than any changes directed at pro play.

If your player base diminishes because the game is not fun, viewership also declines. How many people watch LCS that don't play the game? I did zero research but I'm guessing the number is close to zero.
